Thanks for the fix Bill. I just dug into this after I saw the patch because I remember backward compatibility discussion on the PR introducing the new configs and deprecating the old ones (cf https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2466/files#r113312570). Back than, internally we did not change Streams code to *use* the new `defaultKeySerde`/`defaultValueSerde` but still used the deprecated once (maybe this is part of the issues -- we should have switched immediately instead of calling the deprecated methods). Thus, originally it was backwards compatible as the old method got updated to check for old and new config. However, later on we replaced the old method calls to the new once and this broke it... (cf https://github.com/apache/kafka/commit/2265834803649d2f9fb090e86d11309f6e9789cb)

I am reporting this to give some context, so we can make sure this does not happen in the future again. (\cc @jeyhunkarimov just FYI -- I broke it :(, not you)

However, this raises some questions now: should we first check for the old or new config (it might even be different for the old and new method (maybe the old method should not even consider the new config at all?). What should we do, if we find both configs? Or is this a case we don't need to consider as people would just *change* the config name but never use old and new name at the same time?

Thanks for the PR. A bit of a shame that we are telling users to use a more complicated command. Not sure what was the motivation to encourage people not to use the topic command to update topic configs.
@ijuma TopicCommand.alterTopic is marked as deprecated and I don't know why.  Seems we do recommend user using kafka-configs.sh. Do you think it's okay to have this PR passed though?

I think we should make `keySerde` delegate to `defaultKeySerde`, and `valueSerde` delegate to `defaultValueSerde`, i.e., they should both do the same thing (which they do now with duplicated code). 
However, maybe we should first check for the new config and fall back to the old one if it doesn't exist?

What remains is to actually close streams automatically if threads die, but I'm wondering if it's good enough to tell people to install an exception handler and close. Automatically closing might be a bit of a stretch and might confuse users.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.11/5845/
Test PASSed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.11).

I don't believe this will display the topic and partition that the consumer group subscribes to. Would it be possible to include that information as well. This would be more inline with the 0.9.x behavior. 

The problem is arises when not only when offsets have not been committed but after offsets have expired as well.

@enothereska i think it should be up to the user to decide when to close streams. They might have many threads running and don't really care too much if one dies as it will rebalance and continue, however if some percentage of threads have died, then maybe they will want to kill the instance and restart.
@bbejeck oh i missed the default value. Maybe we just stick with the way it is for now as removing the default value from the new config is not backward compatible from 0.11.0 (i think)

@dguy I completely agree. Closing internally is a complete nightmare.

Thanks @vahidhashemian and @ijuma for taking a look at our patches.  With the latest kafka release now out (congrats!), would there be time for a detailed review of the patches?  We have found the first two:

https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3283/commits/6ee3c167c6e2daa8ce4564d98f9f63967a0efece
https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/3283/commits/a0cd773a8d89d7df90fc75ce55a46fd8bb93d368

to be essential for us in getting kafka to run robustly on Windows.  Our efforts up to this point focused on 0.10.2.1, so we don't expect the patches to fully address 0.11.x on Windows (but they should not introduce any regressions on Linux or Windows) .

If we can get some feedback on the viability our patches, we'd very much like to continue our work and get 0.11.x fully running for us on Windows.

Thanks again!

@guozhangwang @ijuma
@guozhangwang Running system tests. Don't have anything else to add.
LGTM. Please feel free to merge.

@enothereska @dguy I think we should not force setting the instance state to `NOT_RUNNING` at any point except in the `close()` call, even if the global thread dies. One reason is that in the `close()` call, we shutdown the metrics as `metrics.close();` in the shutdown thread as well, if we just set it not running we are at the risk of leaking that metrics object without closing it.
Yup, I think we'll need an `ERROR` state. Clearly if all threads are down, it's none of the current states. @dguy @guozhangwang .

> I guess that means we need another state? If all threads are DEAD then the instance is not in the RUNNING state.

I just had a quick chat with @enothereska offline, and we agreed that over-using `NOT_RUNNING` to indicate both `received user cmd to close and stopped working` and `something wrong happened, and the app stopped working` is risky, for various reasons like leaked resources etc. We can add a different state for the latter case.

Just for the record: the current implementation is geared for cases when the uncaught exception handler calls close(). That will happen before the state transition to NOT_RUNNING. However, point taken, we need another state to totally avoid ambiguity.
LGTM, again :)
@guozhangwang Thanks. I will merge to trunk and 0.11.0 after tests complete.

@murongruomeng Sadly recently I don't have lots of time to maintain this patch outside of the master branch. Would be great if someone could take the effort to update it and get merged. Maybe @xvrl? :)
ok, sounds good to me.
@mjsax @enothereska @guozhangwang - this LGTM as is. Anyone else got anything else to say?

@rajinisivaram there were a bunch of tests which failed due to unexpected threads in a recent run: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/kafka-trunk/2198

What do you make of it?

It looks like the consumer bounce test failed, causing these assertions to fail in following tests:

```
17:40:31 kafka.api.ConsumerBounceTest > testClose FAILED
17:40:31     kafka.common.KafkaException: Socket server failed to bind to localhost:34860: Address already in use.
```

@apurvam If one broker startup fails, we don't shutdown any of the brokers. Hence the failures. As you would have already noticed, it is usually easy to tell from the list of failures the test which actually caused the threads to be left behind (all tests which weren't responsible for the failure have two classMethod failures in setUp and tearDown). Not sure why the address is in use in this failed test though. I suppose we could potentially improve cleanup for this case to avoid the additional failures.
@hachikuji minor doc change.  current description is similar to log.retention.minutes
Port conflicts are an inherent risk with those bounce tests since they use a fixed set of ports per run. Not sure what we can do to cleanup better after we hit this exception though.

@apurvam Yes, you are right, I had forgotten that ConsumerBounceTest was using fixed ports. At the moment, set up does:
```
servers = configs.map(TestUtils.createServer(_)).toBuffer
```
So if one of the brokers could not be created `servers` is not assigned. We can turn this into a for loop that adds to `servers` instead, so that `tearDown` will shutdown any brokers that started successfully. I will submit a PR.
@apurvam Can you take a look? Thank you!
Thanks @ijuma for the quick review!

Running system tests. I keep getting `kafkatest.tests.streams.streams_eos_test.StreamsEosTest.test_failure_and_recovery_complex: FAIL`. @mjsax tells me there is a JIRA for it, but I need to double check and test more. Stay tuned. Turns out to be a network exception, seems like we're having a lot of these: `Exception in thread "main" org.apache.kafka.common.errors.DisconnectException`. Nothing to do with this PR (I believe).
We should include a test to verify this change.
@apurvam @ijuma Thank you for the review. Will merge after builds complete.

@ijuma Unit tests of `NetworkClient` do check that `InflightRequests` works correctly. Obviously, it used to work before because two methods used matching wrong values, but I didn't think there was much value in unit tests for `InflightRequests` just for this change.

@rajinisivaram Ideally we'd have unit tests for classes like `InflightRequests`. They make it less likely that things like this are missed. In this case, it was OK, but we could have had a situation where we started using the incorrect method in some edge case that wasn't exercised in the tests and it would be bad.
